7818271914.title: Multi Channel Artwork
7818271914.content:
A complex thing to enter are the multi channel works.

A multichannel work is always an Installation. The Installation describes the Artwork as totality. The installation can have multiple channels, which are separate Artworks.

To create a Multichannel work:

  • first create the Installation.
  • Then create the Channel.
    When creating it the Master Art field will show all Channel known in the database.
  • Select the Master art to use in the screen.
  • Save the Channel
  • Repeat the creation of Channel for every Channel

When looking at a Multichannel Artwork, the Master Art (the one holding all Channels) has the option Channels in the left column. It will show the list of Channels. The screen can NOT be used to add an extra Channel.
If you select and open a Channel, the left menu will show Channel belongs to. This shows the Master Art of this multi channel Artwork. Here you can edit what Installation is the Master art.

1749492595.title: Search box
1749492595.content:
When searching for a specific Art work or Artist, the searchbox on left can be used to combine the criteria. The information enter is combined into one search question in which all conditions must be true
So when looking for information like Artist is "niels" and year is "1990", we are looking for all artwork made by every artist whose name contains niels and was made in 1990. To select all works made after 1990 we use the the comparing instruction to preceed the value. So if we want to select every artwork that has been made after 1990, we should enter: year is ">1990". The possible compare options are:
  • < the field must be less than the given value.
  • <= the field must be less than or equal to the given value.
  • >= the field must be greater than or equal to the given value.
  • > the field must be greater than to the given value.
  • <> the field must be equal to the given value

1.title: Group configuration
1.content:
Access Groups are the basis for creating special version of the VKA interface.

Menu rights

With the option Menu rights you can define which menu will be shown to the user. Menu's are on many places in the application, like on top the menubar : Home, Search, New art, etc, but also when looking at an Artwork the left part is a menu.

In the top menu you can define if the user can add new Artwork or Artist and which Moderation and System function are shown. Example by removing Site -search the user would not be able to search the site. The System - Processing queue  will remove the Processing queue from the system menu. 

 

Fields access

In this screen you can define whichs rights the Group has on the individual fields. A Field can have 3 state:

  • Editable
    The user can change the field as needed
  • Visible
    The user can only see the field, not change the content
  • Inherited
    The rights are defined by the parent groep and are not changed in this group

Editable and Visible are self explaining. Inherited means that the fields visibility / editability is defined by the parent group of this group. Default all fields are Hidden. Rights can't be revoked; the can only added. Therefor it is important that the parent has the minimal rights, so the children can get more rights (they can edit something the parent group can't).

594245893.title: ResourceSpace logging
594245893.content:
In Resource Space logging is stored in the resource_log table. The fields date, resource and user are self explaining. The resource_type_field is the field stored in the database, it's null if it's an empty creation. Notes is used if an email is send to store the email address. The fields type and diff have special meanings.

the type field

a
Access
Not used by the PNEK interface
b
A batch transform for a slideshow??
c
Create a new resource
No other information is added
d
Download a resource
Not used
e
Update information
Remembers the changes made to a field. The changes are stored in the diff field
E
Send an email to the user.
In the Notes field the email address or username is stored.
l
Found in the log but not in the source: Unknown log entry.
m
Modified
Not used by PNEK
p
A purchase has been done
r
The uploaded file is process with exif.
t
A batch transform has been done.
u
A batch upload is done
x
A resource is removed from an collection.

2445768662.title: File upload and Upload directory
2445768662.content:
There are two ways to add files (resources) to an Artwork. The first way is to upload the file directly on the website, the other way is to use a FTP application to upload the file and then link the uploaded file to the specified Artwork.

Uploading with the browser

Normal file can be directly uploaded to the Artwork. Normal files are small (less the 128 MByte). These files are mostly previews, samples, images or documents belonging to the the Artwork. The upload process is easy. Just select the file and press Upload. A wait line will be shown during the process. After the upload the file is processed with ResourceSpace which still can take some time.
When the process is finished the preview is shown in the application

The file store

Because we are working with video, the size does matter. Original file can be huges. The upload system is limited to 128 MByte, so to upload files of 2 GByte (a normal uncompress video file) should be stored differently. Here the file store comes in handy
The file store is used for LARGE files, more the 128MByte. You just can not upload files beyond that size because the server (The apache server running the application) won’t permit it. So for the original artwork you should use FTP. For this a FTP account is used at the office of PNEK. This FTP applciation can connect to the server and upload the file to the specified directory (Subdirectories are not allowed). If there is an hickup, the FTP application will continue the upload.
When upload they will be shown in the File store listbox. You can select the file and the file will be processed by Resource Space (it can take time for huge files) and the preview is shown.
Ofcause it is important that the name of the file has some logic to it. We propose the atleast the name of the Artist and the title of the Artwork are part of if. It would be handy if know to start the name is the id of the Artwork.
The file store is also used to restore a deleted or overwritten file. The restore file will be places in the File Store so you can link it back to some Artwork. (The restore of deleted files is under System / Delete files).
